importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the annual citizen lobby day in Washington, D.C., when over 500 volunteers from the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network met to lobby Congress on cancer research and policy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe covers the period of the citizen lobbying event in Washington, D.C., during which political polarization and a federal government shutdown created a backdrop for the volunteers to demonstrate bipartisan unity around a shared cause.

keyTakeAways: Cancer does not discriminate based on political affiliation, allowing individuals from diverse political backgrounds to unite around a common cause.
Despite national political divisions, bipartisan support exists for cancer research funding and access to health insurance subsidies, as shown by polling data.
Volunteers from various states, including New York, successfully lobbied 484 congressional offices, focusing on cancer research, screening access, and insurance subsidies.
The event culminated in a candlelight vigil on the National Mall with 10,000 tea lights honoring individuals affected by cancer, emphasizing personal connection and shared experience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In the midst of a federal government shutdown and deep political polarization, over 500 volunteers from the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network, including individuals from diverse political backgrounds such as Mary Catherine Johnson, Lexy Mealing, and John Manna, united in Washington, D.C., to lobby Congress for increased cancer research funding, expanded cancer screening access, and continued health insurance subsidies. Despite differing political affiliations—Johnson voted for Donald Trump three times, Mealing is a Democrat, and Manna is a Reagan Republican—the group emphasized that 'cancer doesn't care,' highlighting a shared personal bond that transcended partisan divides. The event, held on September 16, 2025, saw volunteers visit 484 congressional offices, successfully gaining bipartisan support for research and screening, though insurance subsidies remained a point of contention. The day culminated in a candlelight vigil on the National Mall honoring those impacted by cancer, reinforcing the power of empathy and shared experience in bridging political divides.
title: 'Cancer Doesn't Care': Patients Pushed Past Divisive Politics to Lobby Congress
